executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency.

Rapid advances in computer technology have enabled consumers and small businesses to complete tasks previously performed by quick printing shops from the convenience of their homes and offices. The availability of this technology, combined with swift declines in the price of computer software and peripheral equipment, has hindered shops across the country. Consumers have increasingly favored alternative mediums such as online media and digital communications over printed materials, leeching away the need for quick prints. Overall, revenue is expected to decline at a CAGR of 2.9% during the current period, reaching $4.1 billion in 2023, including a 3.9% decline in 2023 alone. Profit is set to creep downward to 4.7% following rising price competition.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Historically, customers used print shops to print out advertising material. Despite this, print advertising expenditures have fallen significantly as online advertising has become more prominent. The pandemic amplified this trend as many small businesses that previously relied on quick printing services for general and special-event advertising materials have shifted to online channels to achieve finer-tuned consumer targeting.

Businesses relied on print shops for important documents or presentations with strict deadlines. Nowadays, online communication has enabled companies to receive, sign and send documents without ever printing a single page, reducing the need for consistent print shop visits.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: SPECIAL SERVICES HAVE KEPT DEMAND FROM PRINT SHOPS STEADY
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many households and businesses have printers and machines that can fulfill many tasks (e.g. print, fax, copy and scan). To combat this, print shops have focused on specialized or high-value services like document preparation and finishing or producing custom-made promotional and stationary material.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: DIGITALIZATION IS NOT SLOWING DOWN ANYTIME SOON
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The continuously declining print advertising expenditure and the increasing propensity of smaller businesses to complete printing services in-house will continue to hinder revenue. The ever-growing presence of social media will also reduce the need for promotional material and advertising flyers as companies leverage online platforms. Households will also purchase at-home printers as affordable computers and printing machines continue to enter the market, increasing external competition.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: SPECIALIZED STORES ARE THE WAY TO GO
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Quick print shops will attempt to expand into online-based and other high-value digital services. Specifically, companies will focus on specializing in small business services, demonstrating this customer segment as a better avenue for revenue growth. Small businesses will continue to use print services for promotional materials such as signs, stationery and other related items. Direct mail advertisers also use shops to print advertising materials such as coupons, flyers and samples.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Print Shops Will Continue to Deteriorate
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Rising competition will force many print shops to exit or shift to a different line of business. Competition from larger corporations specializing in other sectors (e.g. FedEx, Staples) will continue outperforming print shops by offering a broader range of products and business services. The remaining companies will continue to compete on price and service, pivot toward other product lines and cease to specialize primarily in printing services.

industry_definition: This industry is composed of establishments that provide traditional printing activities, such as short-run offset printing or prepress services, in combination with document photocopying services. Prepress services include receiving documents in electronic format and directly duplicating from the electronic file and then formatting, colorizing and modifying the document to improve presentation.
key_trends: Internal competition remains high as printers compete based on price and location. Convenience is a major deciding factor for consumers and businesses.
Printers have seen significant declines following the shift toward digital communication. Businesses are leaning toward emailing important documents or sheets rather than printing them out.

Start-up costs for quick print shops vary widely based on operation size, requiring essential supplies such as printers, ink and paper. Larger companies often secure long-term contracts with suppliers to keep costs low, impacting their pricing strategies.

Quick printers prioritize convenience and low prices over quality, leading to fierce price competition. This makes location a crucial factor and online services can add a competitive edge by reducing customer downtime.

Advances in computer technology have enabled consumers and small businesses to perform tasks previously done by quick printing shops from their own locations. Affordable printers and equipment continue to bolster this trend.
Consumers favor online media and digital communications, reducing the need for traditional printed materials.

market_segmentation.segment_description: In-store businesses are typically brick-and-mortar locations that use quick print services. These businesses use printing services for labels, flyers, sale papers and other promotional items.

Regular businesses account for the largest market share for printers. Small businesses comprise the bulk of this segment, as they require regular printing of business cards, menus, flyers and other materials.

Household customers represent individuals and families that purchase quick prints. Households' revenue share has fallen significantly, as most homes have purchases a printer that can do tasks for them.
Other markets include government agencies and non-profit organizations.

products_and_services.product_description: Digital printing is better suited for lower-volume projects that require tighter deadlines. It is the most common printing service for walk-in retail customers.

Offset printing is ideal for large quantity printing operations and jobs requiring unconventional or multiple sizing options. This segment's revenue share has declined as digital printing continues to gain popularity.

Prepress services occur between creating a print layout and the final printing. It includes receiving documents in electronic format and directly duplicating them from the electronic file. It also involves formatting, colorizing and modifying the original document to improve presentation.
Bindery services include collating, stapling, fastening and other finishing processes for presenting printed material. Often, these tasks require delicacy and precision to ensure prints look proper.
Other printing services include the production of custom-made promotional and stationery materials.

tier_1_suppliers: Coated & Laminated Paper Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Printing, Paper, Food, Textile & Other Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Design, Editing & Rendering Software Publishing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US
Finance and Insurance in the US
Arts, Entertainment and Recreation in the US
Real Estate and Rental and Leasing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Yearly expenditures on advertising in magazines and newspapers include Sunday magazines, business publications, local magazines, national newspapers and local newspapers. Print advertising is positively correlated with trends in the industry's revenue.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast is a hub for quick printing businesses because of its large population. High population density often correlates with increased demand for various services, including printing.

The Great Lakes region, known for its major cities and high population density, houses numerous quick printing businesses. This is the result of heavy demand for printed materials such as business cards and flyers, essential for both personal and commercial activities.

California has the most significant number of quick printing shops in the United States, driven by its large population and many businesses. The Western United States follows as the second-largest hub for these establishments, largely due to California's significant impact on the market.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Bank check printers must comply with the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, which mandates stringent privacy and information security measures. This federal law requires financial institutions and entities involved with them to protect consumer data carefully. Companies in this industry that produce bank checks face significant regulations to ensure customer information remains confidential and secure, initiating necessary security measures to avert data breaches and ensure compliance.

Federal, state and local environmental laws heavily regulate quick printers. These regulations cover a wide range of areas, including air emissions, waste generation, handling, management, disposal and the remediation of contaminated sites. For instance, printing companies must adhere to the Clean Air Act (CWA), which controls air pollutants from printing equipment. This demands significant investment in compliance measures, impacting operational costs and practices.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Standards
regulations_points.regulation_description: OSHA mandates safe and healthy working environments. For quick printing shops, this means ensuring proper ventilation for chemical fumes, providing safety gear for handling hazardous materials and maintaining all equipment to prevent accidents. Regular inspections and employee training are essential to meet OSHA standards and keep the workplace safe.

basis_points.basis_description: Internal competition remains high as printers compete based on price and location. Convenience is a major deciding factor for consumers and businesses.
Printers have seen significant declines following the shift toward digital communication. Businesses are leaning toward emailing important documents or sheets rather than printing them out.

Start-up costs for quick print shops vary widely based on operation size, requiring essential supplies such as printers, ink and paper. Larger companies often secure long-term contracts with suppliers to keep costs low, impacting their pricing strategies.

Quick printers prioritize convenience and low prices over quality, leading to fierce price competition. This makes location a crucial factor and online services can add a competitive edge by reducing customer downtime.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Quick printers feature numerous local, independent businesses, each catering to niche markets or specific communities. These small operations often provide personalized services that large companies can't match, helping them secure loyal customer bases.
This fragmentation means no single company can dominate the market, resulting in a low overall market share concentration.

Unlike other industries where economies of scale play a significant role, quick printing often relies on rapid turnaround, local market knowledge and customer relationships. The necessity for physical locations close to customers limits the ability of any one company to expand rapidly and take over significant market share.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Weakened need for services hinders profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit comprises less than 5.0% of revenue in this industry because of overcapacity and high competition. As the need for quick prints has crept downward, commercial printers have typically slashed prices to attract new businesses, creating a negative feedback loop in profitability.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Declining revenue has caused wages to drop
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages make up a decent chunk of revenue providers who need to hire designers, prepress technicians, press operations and bindery workers to streamline quick printing processes. Wage costs are difficult to trim because printing is retail-oriented and must staff locations even when business is low. Since quick printers are declining, companies have been leaving the industry or scaling down, causing mass firings of workers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Supplies are essential for quick printing companies
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs include paper, ink, film, offset plates, chemicals and cartons, with paper accounting for the majority of total material costs. These expenses are essential for quick printing businesses to function, so they comprise nearly half of revenue. Purchase costs have remained relatively steady during the current period because of intense price-based competition, which limits a printer's ability to raise prices except in response to material cost hikes.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Quick printers demand significant capital for advanced printing technology and skilled labor to operate and maintain this equipment, raising entry costs and operational complexity for newcomers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The seeds have already been planted
volatility_points.volatility_description: The need for printing has fallen significantly as businesses and individuals seek other forms of advertising. The internet and social media have caused the need for traditional printed material to sink, changing the way advertisers promote their clients. These factors have caused revenue for quick printers to decline drastically. This has fostered large annual shifts in revenue, enhancing volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Economic cycles hit hard and fast
volatility_points.volatility_description: When the economy dips, marketing budgets are one of the first to get slashed. Fewer ads and marketing materials mean less business for quick printers. During economic booms, there's a spike in demand for marketing

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Digital printing revolutionizes speed and flexibility
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Digital printing technology eliminates the need for traditional plates. Quick turnaround times enable same-day and next-day print jobs. On top of this, customization options have grown, allowing for personalized and variable data printing. The cost-effectiveness of short runs also makes digital printing accessible for small businesses.

3D printing offers rapid prototyping and production of complex designs. It enables on-demand manufacturing, reducing waste and storage costs. This form of printing also opens new markets in various industries such as healthcare, automotive and fashion. It also encourages innovation with materials beyond traditional substrates, such as metals and plastics.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: The industry responds to trends in print advertising spending but has been in a state of structural decline driven by new technology.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Players are defined by their printing specialization and effectively exit the industry when they diversify significantly into other services.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: As a service-oriented business, quick printers must be located in relatively expensive, high-traffic areas.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The price of paper fluctuates, and given tense competition, it's often difficult to pass on the increased costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology, such as 3D printing, to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: The industry provides quick, cost-effective printing options and doesn't typically compete heavily on service quality.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations?
FAQs.answer: The industry is retail- and service-oriented and cannot substantially trim its labor expenses.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements embedded in relevant regulations are followed?
FAQs.answer: The industry's employees aren't exposed to significant occupational hazards.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Given the rapid pace of change in the market, consulting a trade group can help businesses adapt their strategy.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Short-run printing is a low-margin activity that has become even less profitable amid dwindling demand.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Printing equipment has a long, useful life and there hasn't been much change in the type of equipment used by quick printers.

FAQs.question: What is your historical performance in meeting consumer expectations? What is your current reputation and how can you improve it?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry need to focus on high-demand markets and profitability.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to ensure your products are well-represented and clearly displayed? Do you have specialized high-quality products?
FAQs.answer: Successful companies must be able to produce high-quality reports, presentations and printed products, as customers rely on quick printing companies for these services.

FAQs.question: Can you access the latest and most efficient technology and techniques? Is your technical expertise to a world standard?
FAQs.answer: New technology can save time, reduce labor costs and improve product quality. Quick printing companies that maximize their use of state-of-the-art technologies and software enhance their competitiveness.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in the number of homes that own computers and peripheral equipment? Have you experienced competition from household use of printers?
FAQs.answer: Since the large majority of homes with printers have computers, the need for these households to visit a quick printing shop has fallen substantially.

FAQs.question: How much of your business is derived from print advertisements? Do you market yourself as a company that prints advertisements?
FAQs.answer: Print advertising is positively correlated with trends in the industry's performance.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your total revenue comes from small or home-based businesses?
FAQs.answer: Small and home-based businesses represent a major market for the industry's services.
